title: Yutaro Mori - Open-sourcing a smart contract, OrcaPod Ep #10

rawLines.text: [Music]
hey pod mates this is ori
welcome to episode 10 of orca pod a deep
dive into d5 from the builder's
perspective
today i'm excited to welcome back my
co-founder utaro to commemorate an
exciting moment for orca we've just open
sourced the smart contract for
whirlpools our concentrated liquidity
smart contract and i know there's a ton
of builders in our community who are
excited to start developing on top of it
so today's episode will be for the devs
in our community it'll be all about

glad to be here again excited to talk

maybe we we start really just at the

leading the engineering team
and setting the direction kind of in

what are you going to build and yeah i

really the motivation here is we are

oral pools is going to be the main way

ecosystem
it's going to be the dominant decks in

and so it's something that we've been

it's hard to believe it's been six weeks

awesome yeah what kind of adoption have

the way i like to describe whirlpools is
first of all it's an amm and so i'm
going to talk with the assumption that
the audience has a vague idea of what an
amm is i'll start there and say that
whirlpools one way of describing it is
it creates a single amm
for kind of a specific price range
and it lines up adjacent one of these
adjacent amms next to each other to
cover the entire possible price range i
think what we could do is really just
start with like why whirlpools is useful
in the first place so for example as
someone who just comes and swaps on orca
why does whirlpools matter to me um in a
nutshell whirlpools
it will give users a better swap
experience both for
the blue chip tokens where there's a ton
of liquidity to be expected kind of like
soul and uscc but also the long tail
tokens the reason why it will give users
a better experience when swapping blue
chip tokens like soul uscc is because
liquidity providers have a lot more
control over how much liquidity they
provide and what kind of uh slippage
they want to provide once when traders
want to trade against the pair and i
think the key point is that it's more
efficient for liquidity providers and so
overall they have to
allocate less capital to provide users a
better experience so basically more
efficient for market makers and as a
result better prices for the swaps right
yeah that's exactly right there's a lot
of nuance you know what makes whirlpools
kind of a great building block for the
salon ecosystem is how robust it is in
the sense that there's no single point
of failure and there's actually pretty

more specifically you know it doesn't

you know we're recording this on may

there's just like a ton of liquidity
problems not just on solana dexes but
centralized exchanges everywhere we as a
team we actually don't have to do

really up to the liquidity provider the
liquidity providers are automatically
incentivized to kind of adjust their
positions
and make decisions in terms of uh you
know where they want to provide their
liquidity how much liquidity they want
to provide it's essentially something
that can just continue functioning
without us intervening at any point in

uh prove to be
incredibly valuable long term yeah
that's something that we've been really
gratified to observe actually right with
the various network disruptions and

last couple of months it's been pretty
cool to see that even when things
essentially grind to a halt as soon as
things start moving again our decks just
kind of automatically starts moving as
well and so i think that's something
that should provide a lot of reassurance
actually to folks who are looking to

because we what we have to offer is like
a very robust base for what you want to

but i want to get a little bit geeky in
this one normally our orca pods stay
pretty high level but again we are
talking to our builders today
so let's actually talk about this
whirlpool smart contract i'll come with
a common question that we get is is it a
fork or
a modification of an existing smart
contract everything is built from
scratch including even like the math
library although you know the the idea
was inspired by kind of the ideas
introduced by unispot v3
and so
if you are familiar with unisoft v3
it'll give you kind of
a sense for how it works although there
are a number of key differences based on
our design philosophy and also based on
the unique constraints of the solana
virtual machine let's get into that so
what what is your unique philosophy that
differentiates the smart contract from
say the univ3 or any other concentrated
liquidity smart contract sure maybe we
can start with kind of solana
constraints because i think that's
that's pretty interesting and that'll
one of your favorite topics yeah
hopefully be like kind of illuminating
for any developers that want to get into
things i think the first one is there's
the concept of ticks we'll call
whirlpools and uni swap v3 concentrated
liquidity amms part of the same family
and you know both
share the concept of ticks and ticks are
basically
kind of discrete markers across
the price range and between ticks are
where you know these miniature amms are
and the way that concentrated liquidity
amms work in general is that for each
tick you need to store data that does
some accounting in terms of how much
liquidity is in each tick or within
two ticks or between two ticks and also
things like fee growth and in our case
reward growth for any given pool there
can be up to almost a million ticks
and each tick
has around i think
90 bytes of data and so if you think
about like the maximum number of data or
data that is required to be stored on
salon is quite large much larger
than something that you'd want to
kind of allocate willy-nilly and also
in the case of whirlpools because
you only need to initialize ticks or you
only care about ticks for prices that
are relevant to the given pair
you don't actually need to initialize
all the ticks what i mean by that
concretely is like let's say
you know we have the sole scc pair in
the past even like two years the prices
range from
let's say like one dollar to 250
but
with whirlpools it's actually possible
to support like
10 to the negative six as a price or
uh 10 to the six as a price so there's
actually a much wider range of prices
that could be supported we only care
about kind of you know a certain subset
of of those possible prices so it's
actually up to the liquidity providers
to allocate those tick ranges
essentially if they if it hasn't been
done before right exactly exactly
the way that it needs to be solved in
solana is a little different from the
way it needs to be solved in ethereum
because of the differences of virtual
machines so in ethereum you can
basically any given contract can
dynamically allocate space on any given
kind of transaction that's being
executed in solana's case it's much more
constrained and you can't just
dynamically allocate more space on the
blockchain it essentially needs to be
pre-allocated the way we do it is we
pack 88 of these ticks
in a given account
and so we require this what we call tick
array
which has a length of 88 to be
initialized
anytime you know liquidity provider
wants to
provide liquidity within a tick in that
tick array
what's kind of interesting about that is
that it makes it a lot more efficient to
access these various ticks
in a swap or even you know anytime that
someone is interacting with the
whirlpool smart contract it makes it a
lot more efficient to
you know access these ticks because
oftentimes
you actually want to like
access ticks that are adjacent to each
other and so instead of having to load
you know the alternate design would be
for
each tick to be a single account but
then you know it's possible in certain
cases
that
a user will
you know need to access say like 10
ticks and then they would have to pass
in 10 accounts in our case it's a lot
more efficient to pass in these ticker
rays got it so it does essentially fall
on these folks who are creating the
pools for the first time much of the
time to initiate or initialize these
ticks right because that's something
that i remember
users actually being a little surprised
by during the betas like the cost of
initializing all these tick arrays for
these very new pools yeah if i recall
right now it's around um
it was kind of like low single digits in
dollar terms you know the flip side
actually is that you know the cost to
initialize the pool is basically cents
and on top of that you need to
initialize at least one tick array
maybe two and that's kind of low single
digits so it's still kind of incredibly
reasonable when it comes to
you know the cost of creating a new pool
got it yeah i think both the cost and
the ease are things that are pretty
exciting we're really hoping that
everyone will be able to use whirlpools
for whatever tokens they want liquidity
for right in the ecosystem so i think
this is actually a smart trade-off as

touched a little bit on the math library
and i know that's something our dev team

sure so um
in our contract we need to do 256-bit

in rus the sander library only supports

the library itself that they wrote is

it was incredibly expensive so you know

it oftentimes costs 10 000 cpu for a

and just to get a sense of scale you

so basically you can only do you know 10

of that budget for other things as well

and so
